title: Charlie Haughey refused possibly life-saving operation because it would make him impotent, says historian
text:
Charlie Haughey refused possibly life-saving operation because it would make him impotent, says historian 15:30, 22 Oct 2015 By Keeley Ryan Tim Pat Coogan's tale about the former Taoiseach is in his new book The Mornings After   Thanks   The story of Haughey's illness is part of Coogan's new book, The Mornings After 
Charlie Haughey refused an operation that could have extended his life because it would have made him impotent, according to historian Tim Pat Coogan. 
In his new book, the historian told how Haughey was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 1996 - and was also told that if the prostate was removed, he would survive. 
Coogan added: "However, he was also informed that the operation would render him impotent. 
"He refused to undergo the procedure, even though he was warned that in all probability the cancer would thereby spread and kill him. 
"He refused the operation saying: 'No, there's life in the old man yet'." 
The former Taoiseach passed away in 2006. 
In his new book The Mornings After, about Ireland's history since 1916, Coogan includes stories about Haughey, Ian Paisley and Bishop Eamon Casey - among many others.
